metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip for the point-of-care detection of emerging and re- emerging enteric coronaviruses in swine Microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip for the point-of-care detection of 1 emerging and re-emerging enteric coronaviruses in swine

abstract.text: Microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip for the point-of-care detection of emerging and re-emerging enteric coronaviruses in swine, Analytica Chimica Acta, https://doi.Abstract 29 Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV), porcine deltacoronavirus (PDCoV), and 30 swine acute diarrhea syndrome-coronavirus (SADS-CoV) are three emerging and 31 re-emerging coronaviruses (CoVs). Symptoms caused by these three viruses are 32 extremely similar, including acute diarrhea, vomiting and even death in piglets. To 33 date, strict biosecurity is still the most effective disease prevention and control 34 measures, and the early detection of pathogens is the most important link. Here, we 35 developed a microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip detection system for the first time, which 36 could detected PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV simultaneously, and had advantages of 37 rapid, simple, sensitive, high-throughput, and accurate at point-of-care settings. The 38 lowest detection limits of the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip method are 10 1 copies/μL, 39 10 2 copies/μL and 10 2 copies/μL for PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV, respectively. The 40 whole detection procedure can be finished rapidly in 40 min without any 41 cross-reaction with other common swine viruses. A total of 173 clinical swine fecal 42 samples characterized with diarrheal symptoms were used to evaluate the 43 performance of the newly developed system, which presented good stabilities 44 3 (C.V.s<5%) and specificities (100%), and possessed sensitivities of 92.24%, 92.19% 45 and 91.23% for PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV respectively. In summary, the 46 established microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip detection system could satisfy the demanding 47 in field diagnoses, which was suitable for promotion in remote areas due to its fast, 48 portable and cost-effective characters. 49 50

body_text.text: Diarrhea disease is one of major threats that afflict the global pork industry in 55 recent years, which has caused an estimated loss of multi-million dollar annually. 56 Various pathogens that can cause diarrhea in swine have been identified, and swine 57 enteric coronaviruses are the most destructive pathogens that are able to result 58 vomiting, dehydration and lethal watery diarrhea in piglets [1] . To date, four swine 59 enteric coronaviruses have been defined, including three Alphacoronaviruses widely applied for detecting and identifying pathogens [27] [28] [29] [30] . 89 Up to now, the predominant control measures of swine diarrhea disease are the 90 rapid and accurate diagnoses of pathogens at the early stage to prevent further 91 circulations in swine. Currently, the most commonly detection methods for swine 92 enteric coronaviruses such as ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay), PCR and 93 IHC (immunohistochemistry), all depend on laboratory diagnosis and possessed the 94 advantages of high sensitivity and accuracy, and have been widely used [31] [32] [33] [34] . 95 However， most of these diagnostic assays are complex, time-consuming, and require a 96 large of reagents and well-equipped laboratories, which limit their application in 97 remote areas. Therefore, it is urgent to develop portable POC devices with characters 98 of simple, timely, multi-target and strong pertinence, so as to detect pathogens early, showed that the developed microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system was accurate, 111 sensitive, specific and reproducible for point-of-care diagnosis, which was advantaged 112 for the early diagnosis of diarrhea in swine farms, especially in remote areas, and 113 adopting effective measures to control the spread of the diseases. The microfluidic chip made of PMMA that was used in this study was a CD-shape 132 with a diameter of 80 mm and a thickness of 2.5 mm, which was fabricated by the 133 micro-injection molding technology. To form an integrated microfluidic chip, a kind 134 of pressure-sensitive film was applied to seal the micro-channel of chip via suitable 135 pressure. The microfluidic chip comprised four independent units, each of which was 136 consisted of a sample well, a vent and eight micro reaction wells ( Figure 1A ). The 137 ball valve played a significant role throughout the process ensuring that the reaction 138 mixture diffused into the adjacent pipe and the reaction wells were filled with liquid.

The volume of each micro reaction well was 5 μL. The supporting microfluidic To ensure the accuracy of the three LAMP systems, the amplification products were 172 further determined by standard agarose gel electrophoresis. Table 1 .

To determine the accuracy of the LAMP reaction, the target templates were 227 successfully amplified from the target-contained sample and presented ladder-like 228 bands with agarose gel electrophoresis ( Figure 2D ). 287 The specificity, sensitivity and reproducibility test results have illustrated that the 288 microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip detection system is stable, rapid, convenient and portable.
To further verify the actual performance of the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip detection

FIGREF0.text: 99 prevent the spread of infectious disease and reduce mortality. Amongst the various 100 biosensor-based methods that have been reported, centrifugal microfluidic 101 lab-on-a-chip (LOC) is the most recent innovation tool in microfluidic field, which 102 can make analytical assays perform in a multiple, high throughput and integrated 103 format with high efficiency and speed [35, 36]. Centrifugal microfluidic devices 104 actually have the CD-like chip combining microfluidic unit operations, such as liquid 105 mixing, metering, aliquot, switching, valving and storage, which are controlled by the 106 centrifugal speed of the chip [37, 38]. 107 In the present study, we integrated the real-time reverse transcription loop-mediated 108 isothermal amplification (RT-LAMP) into the CD-like microfluidic chip for rapid and 109 convenient multiplex detection of PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV. Our results 6

FIGREF1.text: 1. Clinical samples, nucleic acid extraction and qRT-PCR assays 117 Clinical diarrheal samples including feces and intestinal contents were collected 118 from swine in southern China in accordance with the recommendations of National 119 Standards for Laboratory Animals of the People's Republic of China 120 (GB149258-2010). Samples were preserved at -80 ℃ from the time of original receipt 121 until use. 122 Samples were homogenized in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) (20% w/v), frozen 123 and thawed three times, then centrifuged for 10 min at 10,000 g. Viral nucleic acid 124 was extracted following the manufacturer's recommendations of Magnetic Viral 125 DNA/RNA Kit (iGeneTech, Ningbo, China

FIGREF2.text: 140 detection equipment (dimensions: length, width, and height are 280 × 200 × 135 mm) 141 was actually a device (Product Model: AJYGene TM MA2000) that was equipped 142 with the functions of constant temperature control, high-speed centrifugation and 143 fluorescence reading and analysis, and was provided by iGeneTech (Ningbo, China).

FIGREF3.text: Once microfluidic detection equipment starts running, the sample would be145 uniformly distributed in each reaction chambers at two step centrifugal forces (1600 146 RPM/min, 30 sec and 4600 RPM/min, 10 sec). While the reaction was performed at 147 the given temperature, the microfluidic device gathered fluorescence signals of each 148 micro chambered every minute and displayed in real time on the electronic screen.

FIGREF4.text: complete genomic sequences of PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV 152 were retrieved from Genbank with accession numbers of KT323979.1, KY078891, 153 MG557844, respectively. Based on the highly conserved PEDV M, PDCoV N and 154 PrimerExplorer V5 online software ((https://primerexplorer.jp/lampv5/index.html) 156 and synthesized by BGI (Shenzhen, China).

FIGREF5.text: 4 . Primer screen and integrated microfluidic-RT-LAMP system159    First of all, the primers corresponding to different viruses were pre-immobilized in

FIGREF6.text: 160 eight reaction chambers by heating drying. Six micro chambers were employed for 161 detections of three viruses with one repetition, and the remaining two were used for 162 negative controls (Figure 1B). The related primer mixture was pre-loaded into the 163 reaction holes. Secondly, the real-time RT-LAMP reaction solution was prepared in a 164 volume of 10.2 μL comprising 50 μM SYBR Green (Invitrogen,USA), 800 U/μL of 165 Bst DNA polymerase (New England BioLabs, USA) , 5000 U/mL of AMV 166 transcripitase (New England BioLabs, USA) and 40 U/μL RNase inhibitor (Vazyme, 167 China). The premixed reaction solution containing 14.8 μL of nucleic acid was 168 injected into sample wells of the microfluidic chip directly by pipette, and then 169 sample wells and vent wells were sealed by the film. The preprocessed microfluidic 170 chip was then placed in the provided microfluidic device to react at 63.5 ℃ for 60 min.

FIGREF8.text: Generally, the amplification result was regarded as positive only when experiments 174 with one repetition shows a positive signal and the negative controls show negative 175 signals in 60 min. A complete set of procedures was showed inFigure 1C.

FIGREF9.text: investigate the specificity, 11 other swine viruses including porcine parvovirus 180 (PPV), Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2), classical 181 swine fever virus (CSFV), porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus 182 (PRRSV), pseudo rabies virus (PRV), swine influenza virus (SIV), foot and mouth 183 disease virus (FMDV), seneca valley virus (SVA), rotavirus (RV) and transmissible 184 gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) were employed for testing. RNase Free ddH 2 O was also 185 contained in the run as negative control.

FIGREF10.text: examine the detection limit of three RT-LAMP systems, in vitro-transcribed 188 RNA standards of PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV were diluted serially ten-fold with 189 RNase free ddH 2 O (10 6 -10 0 copies/μL) as templates and performed in three different 190 times. The in vitro-transcribed RNA standards were prepared according to the 191 previously reported method [37].

FIGREF11.text: Stability and repeatability analysis193    In order to confirm the stability and repeatability of three developed LAMP 194 systems, ten-fold serial standards dilutions with high (10 6 copies/μL), medium (10 4 195 copies/μL) and low (detection limits of three coronavirus tested by196 microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system) concentrations were used to evaluate 197 coefficients of variation (C.V.) of the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip. The assay for time 198 to threshold values (Tt), defined as the reaction time required for a particular sample 199 reach sufficiently positive signals above the baseline during the real-time 200 amplification, were both included in repeated eight times. The threshold for choosing 201 the Tt was based on the fluorescence value of the negative controls of each test. Three 202 clinical samples were also conducted to determine the stability and reproducibility of 203 the developed microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system. 204 205 2.6. Microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip and qRT-PCR for the detection of clinical samples 206 A total of 173 swine clinical fecal samples characterized with diarrheal symptoms 207 were collected and detected by the developed microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system. 208 Samples being amplified in 60 min and showing the typical amplification curves were 209 considered to be positive. At the same time, the diagnostic accuracy of the 210 microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system was compared with the qRT-PCR assays, and 211 was further evaluated by generating receiver operating characteristic curves (ROCs, Screening primers for three emerging and re-emerging swine coronaviruses 216 Several sets of LAMP primers were designed and screened for PEDV, PDCoV and 217 SADS-CoV, and one for each pathogen was selected respectively to conduct the 218 following experiments. The in vitro transcribed RNA of each coronavirus was used as 219 template. 220 After the temperature reached to 63.5 ℃ for LAMP reaction, the fluorescence 221 signals were recorded for each hole every minute. Obvious S-shaped amplification 222 curves were observed on the display if successful experiments were processed. As 223 shown in Figure 2 (A-C), PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV could be amplified by the 224 candidate primers, and the primer set 3 (PEDV), 3 (PDCoV) and 4 (SADS-CoV) were 225 selected, respectively. The primer sequences used in this study were listed in

FIGREF12.text: Evaluation of the detection performance of the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip 230 system 231 3.2.1 Specificity and sensitivity 232 To assess the specificity of the screened LAMP primers, 11 relevant swine viral 233 nucleic acid including that of CSFV, PPV, JEV, PCV2, PRRSV, PRV, SIV, FMDV, 234 SVA, RV and TGEV were applied in this study. As shown in Figure 3 (A-C) only 235 PEDV-, SADS-CoV-and PDCoV-positive samples presented obvious amplification 236 curves, and 11 other pathogens and the control water displayed negative reactions, 237 which illustrated the high specificity of the established microfluidic-RT-LAMP assay. 238 Taken together, the fluorescence curves during the amplification demonstrated that the 239 system had no cross reaction with other common swine viruses and possessed a high 240 degree of specificity. 241 After evaluating the specificity of the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip detection system, the serially diluted plasmids carrying the highly conserved genes of PEDV, 243 PDCoV and SADS-CoV respectively were initially utilized to investigate the lowest 244 detection limits of the established microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system for each virus. F showed that the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system enabled the 246 detection of PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV within 40 min and the detection limit for 247 each of the three viruses were maintained at 10 1 copies/μL, 10 2 copies/μL and 10 2 248 copies/μL, respectively. Those detection limits of this system were competitive for the 249 application to POC diagnostic device [39-41]. The sample-to-answer time on-chip for 250 diagnosis, including nucleic acid extraction, adding reaction solution, sealing and 251 reaction, was approximately 1.5 h. On the other hand, the total volume of sample and 252 reaction buffer used for one on-chip detection hole was roughly 25 μL. Undoubtedly, 253 the new method developed here was a cost-effective and time-saving way for PEDV, 254 PDCoV, and SADS-CoV diagnosis with POC platform when compared with existing 255 methods [39-41]. In addition, the semi-logarithmic regression analysis was performed 256 using the data from the sensitivity test results of standard samples (Figure 3G-I). 257 There was a significant linear relationship between the logarithm of the plasmid 258 concentration and the Tt value for PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV with the R 2 values 259 of 0.965, 0.9827 and 0.9572, respectively, which indicated the potential quantitative 260 detection capability of this established diagnosis platform. Effective development of 261 diagnostic platform such as microfluidic chip requires ultrahigh sensitivity and 262 specificity to enable real-time analysis needed for clinical detection [42]. Based on 263 above data, the established microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip detection system is 13 competitive and competent in POC diagnosis of PEDV, PDCoV and SADSalso an important indicator for a diagnostic method [43]. For this part, 270 the high, medium and low detectable concentration standard samples were used to 271 validate the reproducibility and stability of the established microfluidic-RT-LAMP 272 chip detection system. We calculated the C.V. through dividing the standard deviation 273 (SD) by the mean of different samples at the same concentration. The results of Figure 274 4 A-C demonstrated the stability of our method. For the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip 275 detection system, the C.V. values of the standard samples of PEDV, PDCoV and 276 SADS-CoV ranged from 2.52% to 3.43%, 1.78% to 2.29% and 2.59 % to 3.75% 277 respectively with small SDs (Figure 4 G-I). All the above C.V. values were less than 278 5%, indicating the good reproducibility of each established microfluidic-RT-LAMP 279 chip method. The results were further confirmed by the clinical PEDV-, PDCoV-and 280 SADS-CoV-infected fecal samples (Figure 4D-F), which showed ideal C.V. values of 281 3.71%, 2.43% and 1.69% for each coronavirus (Figure G-I). In summary, the 282 developed CD-like microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system for the point-of-care 283 diagnosis of multiple genes of PEDV, PDCoV and SADS-CoV is promising, and can 284 be applied to the real-time qualitatively monitoring of these three coronaviruses with 285 high specificity, sensitivity and rapidity.

FIGREF14.text: 290 system in clinical samples, we collected 173 swine diarrhea samples, of which 80 291 PEDV positive samples, 59 PDCoV positive samples, 52 SADS-CoV positive 292 samples and 17 negative samples were detected by the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip 293 system and referenced qRT-PCR assays. There were 12 samples co-infected with two 294 or three coronaviruses. No negative sample detected by the qRT-PCR assays was 295 found to be positive by the developed microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system. The 296 coincidence rates (the proportion of the number of samples with the same test results 297 in the total number of test samples) of the detection results between the qRT-PCR and 298 the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system were 97.69%, 97.11% and 97.11% for PEDV, 299 PDCoV and SADS-CoV, respectively (Table 2). Sensitivities of the 300 microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip for each virus were 95.24%, 92.19% and 91.23%. 301 Additionally, specificities of the microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip for three viruses were 302 all 100%. The results were matched perfectly, which showed that our 303 microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system was effective and reliable. 304 Based on the above dates, ROCs were plotted to determine the diagnostic accuracy 305 of the microfluidic-RT-LAMP system and qRT-PCR assays. The results revealed that 306 the AUC ROC were 0.976, 0.961 and 0.956 (p<0.0001) for PEDV, PDCoV and and 0.9123, which indicated the detection system we developed is an effective 309 diagnostic tool to distinguish three kinds of coronaviruses infected and uninfected 310 samples, with the potential to replace existing methods for POC diagnosis (Figure 311 5A-C) [39-41]. Simultaneously, ROC curves of the microfluidic-RT-LAMP system 312 and qRT-PCR assays were analyzed, and the results further showed that there was no 313 significant difference between these two kinds of methods in detecting these three 314 coronaviruses (Z PEDV =2.037, p<0.0416; Z PDCoV =2.311, p<0.0209; Z SADS-CoV =2.320, 315 p<0.0203) (Figure 5A-C).

FIGREF15.text: together, this study successfully established a rapid, simple and low-cost 319 multiplex detection tool for PEDV, PDCoV, and SADS-CoV, which integrated a 320 microfluidic chip, real-time RT-LAMP assay and a portable microfluidic chip 321 fluorescence detector. The entire procedure could be completed within 1.5 h at 322 detection limits of 1×10 1 copies/μL, 1×10 2 copies/μL and 1×10 2 copies/μL for PEDV, 323 PDCoV and SADS-CoV, respectively. Perfect sensitivity and specificity for those 324 three swine coronaviruses detection were also found with 173 clinical samples. This 325 microfluidic-RT-LAMP chip system possesses the important features of a successful 326POC diagnostic tool, in that it is extremely portable, cost-effective and rapid.

FIGREF16.text: Meanwhile, it is high-throughput and easy-to-use in the field, which has given the 328 excellent prospects of this method in swine enteric coronaviruses epidemic 329 monitoring and control.

CR: coincidence rate. CR = (True positive + True negative)/Total*100%
